content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines a State as a State of the United States, the District of Columbia, and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas and establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in those areas. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" allows for Federal assistance in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas by establishing criminal street gang enforcement teams consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders. Personnel can be reassigned or detailed from any Federal department or agency for this purpose. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" authorizes the reassignment of personnel from Federal departments or agencies to criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. It also provides necessary funding for the operation and meetings of these teams to ensure effective operation. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" authorizes the formation of criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. These teams consist of agents and officers from various federal agencies and receive funding for meetings to share intelligence and best practices. The formation of criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under the "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" includes agents and officers from various federal agencies, state and local law enforcement, and prosecutors. The Attorney General considers specific criteria when designating an area for this purpose. The Attorney General considers criteria such as current and predicted levels of gang crime activity, the relationship between violent crime and gang activity, and the commitment of resources by state and local law enforcement agencies when designating an area as a high-intensity interstate gang activity area. The Attorney General considers various criteria when designating an area as a high-intensity interstate gang activity area, including the extent of resources committed by law enforcement agencies, the potential impact of increased federal resources, and any other relevant factors deemed appropriate. The Attorney General may hire up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities in designated high-intensity interstate gang areas. Appropriations are authorized as needed for this purpose. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims of crimes. Grants under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 are amended to hire more prosecutors, fund technology and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders, and reduce backlogs. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to authorize funding for technology, equipment, and training to accurately identify and prosecute young violent offenders. Authorization of $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 for grants to establish state-wide crime prevention databases. Grants will be awarded to State and local law enforcement programs to establish State-wide crime prevention databases, with authorization of necessary appropriations.
